questions.text: 1. A 55-year-old man was admitted for evaluation under neurology with complaints of dizziness on standing and difficulty maintaining balance while walking. Uncontrolled urination was noted along with rigidity of the upper and lower limbs. No signs of olfactory complaints or memory disorders were noted. Which of the following MRI findings contribute to the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of Multiple System Atrophy (MSA) or Shy Drager syndrome, which on MRI shows a 'hot cross bun' sign, as seen in image 3.

Multiple system atrophy is more common in men above the age of 50, and presents as autonomic failure with symptoms of Parkinsonism (MSA-P) or cerebellar syndrome (MSA-C). Clinical features include rigidity, early loss of urinary control, erectile dysfunction, and orthostatic hypotension, which may manifest as dizziness on standing. Female patients and patients with early autonomic signs and bladder dysfunction have a poor prognosis.

A characteristic 'hot cross bun' sign (given in the image below) due to T2 hyperintensity and cerebellar atrophy is seen on an MRI in the pons in MSA-C. On the other hand, MSA-P is characterized by iron deposition in the striatum. Patients are generally given symptomatic treatment based on the severity and range of symptoms.



It can be differentiated from Parkinson's Disease, which presents with asymmetric, slowly progressive rigidity and rest tremor; it typically responds well to levodopa; autonomic dysfunction is mild and late, not as severe or early as in MSA.​ MSA-P is Parkinsonian type, characterized by more rigidity, bradykinesia, and poor levodopa response, but ataxia and autonomic problems predominate. Whereas in MSA-C, prominent cerebellar signs (gait instability, ataxia), pronounced early autonomic dysfunction, and fewer Parkinsonian features are seen.

Other options

Option A: Image 2 shows the characteristic 'hummingbird sign', seen in progressive supranuclear palsy(PSP), a parkinson plus syndrome. It classically presents with early falls, vertical gaze palsy, and axial rigidity. Lack of gaze palsy, frontal/executive dysfunction, and characteristic MRI clinchers help rule out PSP here.​



Option B: Image 1 shows a T1-weighted MRI showing normal brain anatomy – ventricles, cortex, and white matter appear normal, which does not support a degenerative process.



Option C: Image 4 is a T2-weighted image showing cortical tubers, white matter abnormalities, and subependymal nodules, classic for tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC).  TSC features multiple cortical/subcortical tubers, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, and white matter radial migration lines—none of which fit this patient’s clinical scenario.​

questions.text: 2. A 65-year-old patient presents with a diabetic foot. The plan is to amputate the foot at the level of A-B as shown below. What is the amputation at this level called?
questions.solution:
This level of amputation is called Syme's amputation.

Syme's amputation is the amputation at the level of the distal tibia and fibula, 0.6 cm proximal to the periphery of the ankle joint, passing through the dome of the ankle. It is the most satisfactory functional level in the lower extremity when the outcome is good.

The most common causes of an unsatisfactory Syme stump are posterior migration of the heel pad and skin slough resulting from overly vigorous trimming of “dog ears” or a compromised posterior tibial artery. The chief objection to this amputation is cosmetic.

Sarmiento modification of the Syme technique is the transection of the tibia and fibula approximately 1.3 cm proximal to the ankle joint and excision of the medial and lateral malleoli.

questions.text: 3. Results of various studies carried out to study the role of smoking in breast cancer are plotted below. Which of these studies are statistically insignificant?
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of a forest plot used for plotting the results of a meta-analysis. Any study whose confidence intervals touch the "line of no effect" is considered statistically insignificant. In this given plot Studies A, B, and C are touching the line of no effect and hence are statistically insignificant.

A forest plot/blobbogram is used to present the results of a meta-analysis. It allows the results to be seen at a glance, with ready identification of outliers. Each study is represented as a rectangle and a horizontal line. The size of the rectangle represents the sample size of the study. The horizontal line on either side of the result shows the 95% confidence interval surrounding the point estimate.

The vertical solid line is the “line of no effect,” where there is no difference between having the risk factor and the absence of the risk factor. (i.e., a risk ratio of zero). If any study touches this line such a study is statistically insignificant.

In other words, when the confidence intervals of a study include an Odds Ratio of 1.0, that study is statistically insignificant. A forest plot also compares individual studies, for deciding whether a drug is significantly better than a placebo or not.

Pearl PM1149: Forest Plot

* A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.

* It is also called blobbogram.



Interpretation of forest plots: 

* The rectangles represent the single studies

* The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size

* The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results

* The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 

* The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not

* A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged

* Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.

* The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 



* For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.

* For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: 4. A 52-year-old man dies in a road traffic accident and is identified as a registered eye donor. The retrieval team reaches the body 4 hours after death. Which of the following statements regarding eye donation is correct?

choices.text: Retrieval can be done till 24 hours after death
Donor's age should be between 18 to 50 years for eye donation
Donor tissue can be retrieved using whole globe enucleation
The whole globe can be used for direct transplantation

questions.solution:
Donor tissue can be retrieved using whole globe enucleation is a correct statement regarding eye donation.

Eye banks use two surgical retrieval methods: whole globe enucleation, where the eyeball is removed and processed later to remove the corneoscleral rim under sterile conditions, or in-situ corneoscleral rim excision, where the cornea is harvested directly at the site. In both methods, tissues are preserved in storage media and transported in cold conditions. In both of these methods of retrieval, only the corneas (not the whole globe) are processed and preserved in specialised storage media at 4 degrees Celsius until they are distributed for transplantation (option D).

Retrieval must be done within 6 hours of death (option A). Eye donation can be pledged by individuals of nearly any age, as long as they have a healthy and clear cornea (option B). The medium used to store the donor corneal graft is McCarey Kaufman medium. Cornea can be transplanted immediately or preserved in an eye bank using various preservation techniques for different intervals:

* Short-term preservation (24 to 96 hours) - A moist chamber or McCarey–Kaufman medium is used.

* Intermediate-term preservation (up to 2 weeks) - Medium containing chondroitin sulphate is used.

* Long-term preservation (up to months to years) - Preserved up to 1 year by cryopreservation in liquid nitrogen or glycerol.

Donors are evaluated through medical history, physical exam, and blood tests for infections like HIV, hepatitis B and C, and syphilis. Conditions such as active sepsis, certain cancers, rabies, unknown neurological disorders, or unexplained death make a donor unsuitable due to the risk of disease transmission. A single eye donation can restore vision in two individuals, as each cornea is transplanted to a different recipient. Eyes are never bought or sold, and donations are never turned down.

questions.text:
5. A microbiology laboratory is tasked with performing antimicrobial testing on a blood culture isolate of Klebsiella pneumoniae. The technician uses E-Test for this. Which of the following statements best describes the key advantage of the E-test over the standard Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method?

E-test - Epsilometer test

choices.text: The E-test is a quantitative method that determines MIC
The E-test is an automated system that provides resistance results within 4 hours
The E-test is a qualitative method that provides results based on the zone of inhibition
The E-test is the only method that can detect inducible resistance

questions.solution:
The E-test is a quantitative technique used to determine the minimum inhibitory concentration(MIC) of an antimicrobial agent. It combines the basic concepts of both dilution and diffusion methods.

E-Test provides the exact Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) value for an antibiotic directly on the agar plate.​ It uses a strip with a gradient of antibiotic concentration. The MIC is read at the point where the elliptical zone of inhibition intersects the scale on the strip. This information helps in precise antibiotic dosing decisions, crucial for severe or resistant infections, and can be more informative for clinical decision-making when compared to only qualitative (S/R/I) results.

The given image shows the E-test:



The Kirby-Bauer Disk Diffusion Method is a qualitative test that categorizes isolates as Sensitive, Intermediate, or Resistant based on the diameter of the zone of inhibition.​ However, it does not provide an actual MIC value; only the presence and size of the inhibition zone are interpreted using reference standards.

The image below shows the Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method:



Other options:

Option B: The E-test is a manual, not automated, technique and usually requires overnight incubation to read results. Automated systems like VITEK 2 or Phoenix provide rapid results. Option C: While the E-test involves a zone of inhibition, its distinctive feature is providing a quantitative MIC value. Kirby-Bauer is the classic qualitative zone-based method.

Option D: Detection of inducible resistance (e.g., inducible clindamycin resistance) generally requires specific tests (e.g., D-test) and is not a unique feature of the E-test. Both disk diffusion and molecular methods can be used for this purpose.

questions.text: 6. A 55-year-old man was admitted with the inability to flex his neck and a fever for 2 days. The microbiological tests performed are shown in the images below. Culture showed growth of an organism resistant to penicillin. The patient was started on empirical therapy, which included drug X, known to cause flushing and redness on the torso, face, and neck. What does the drug inhibit to cause its antimicrobial action?

choices.text: Cell wall synthesis by binding to D-alanyl-D-alanine
Protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosome
Cell wall synthesis by preventing cross-linking of glycan chains
Protein synthesis  by binding to the 50S ribosome

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the observed flushing and redness over the torso, face, and neck during infusion are characteristic of "red man syndrome," caused by Vancomycin, which acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis by binding to D-alanyl-D-alanine.

In the scenario above, the Gram-positive organism with a positive quellung test(capsular swelling), along with the clinical symptoms, is suggestive of community-acquired meningitis caused by penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae.

The bacterial cell wall has long chains of peptidoglycan, which are cross-linked to each other by the enzyme transglycosylase. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide group of antibiotics that binds to the D-alanyl-D-alanine terminus of the synthesised peptidoglycan. This inhibits the transglycosylase enzyme and prevents elongation and cross-linking of peptidoglycan. This results in weakening of the cell wall, causing lysis.

Vancomycin shows antimicrobial activity against penicillin-resistant streptococci, MRSA, and ampicillin-resistant enterococci. Though it is known to act against gram-positive organisms, Lactobacillus and Erysipelothrix are intrinsically resistant, along with gram-negative bacteria. This is due to the large molecular size of the drug, which prevents it from entering the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria.

Therapeutic uses include treatment of MRSA suspected pneumonia, endocarditis, vascular catheter-related infections, and penicillin-resistant streptococcal meningitis. Oral vancomycin is also used in Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhoea.

Adverse effects include rapid infusion-related urticarial and erythematous reaction leading to flushing of the neck, face, and torso. Therefore, the infusion rate should be less than 1g/hour. Dose-dependent nephrotoxicity is also seen, which is more prevalent when administered with penicillin.

Other options:

Option B: Inhibition of protein synthesis, with action on 30S ribosomes, is seen with drugs like tetracyclines and aminoglycosides like streptomycin.

Option C: Beta-lactam antibiotics are known to cause antimicrobial activity by inhibiting the cross-linking of glycan chains.

Option D: Inhibition of protein synthesis by binding to the 50S subunit of the ribosome is carried out by macrolides and streptogramins.

questions.text: 7. A middle-aged hypertensive man presents with acute onset pain and swelling on his toe over the left foot. Local examination showed a swelling over the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot, as shown below. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs can be safely administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with acute onset pain and swelling over the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot suggests the diagnosis of acute gout. Losartan can be safely administered to this patient as it is a uricosuric drug.

Losartan is competitive angiotensin I (AT1) receptor antagonist, which binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. Uses of losartan are:

* Antihypertensive

* Renoprotective drug in diabetes mellitus

* Stroke prophylaxis

* Portal hypertension in cirrhosis without compromising renal function

* Anti-aggregant as it is a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor 

* Uricosuric drug as it inhibits reabsorption and actively secretes uric acid in the proximal convoluted tubule

Adverse effects include fetopathic potential, hypotension, renal insufficiency, and hyperkalemia. 

Other options:

Option B: Atenolol is a beta blocker that has been proven to increase serum uric acid levels; hence, it is avoided.

Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic; it is not used in patients with gout as it increases the uric acid level.

Option D: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that causes hyperuricemia due to increased reabsorption of uric acid. It is not used in patients with gout.

Pearl PM1929: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs Aspirin (low dose) Niacin Thiazide Lasix (furosemide) Ethambutol Alcohol Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text:
8. A medical officer was conducting a study of all medicolegal cases seen in the emergency department of a tertiary care hospital. Which of the following cases will be considered under BNS 116?

* Vitriolage causing permanent disfiguration of the face.

* Assault leading to mouth trauma, causing 2 central incisors to fall out.

* Collision with a scooter while walking, leading to contusion over the right thigh and fracture of the left knee. 

* A 16-year-old girl who has impaired vision in her left eye due to vitreal haemorrhage, but no other facial injuries.

* Loss of hearing in one ear following a blow to the head during an assault.
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1, 2, 3 and 5.

Section 116 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) is associated with the definition of grievous hurt. This includes:

* Emasculation

* Permanent loss of hearing in either ear

* Permanent loss of sight in either eye

* Permanent loss of a member or joint

* Permanent loss of function of a member or joint

* Fracture of a bone or tooth (Statement 2, 3)

* Permanent disfiguration of the face (Statement 1)

* Any injury that endangers life or causes the victim bodily pain severe enough to warrant at least 15 days of hospital admission or an inability to carry out his/her daily activities.

The 16-year-old girl, who has impaired vision in her left eye due to vitreal haemorrhage, but no other facial injuries(statement 4), has only suffered temporary privation/partial loss of function - hence would not be considered as grievously hurt.

questions.text: 9. A 2-week-old infant presented with severe jaundice. On examination, he had a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. Investigations revealed cholestatic jaundice, elevated liver enzymes, and imaging findings as shown below. According to the Todani classification used in this disease, which type opens into the duodenum?
questions.solution:
The clinical history, as well as the imaging findings shown above, suggest a diagnosis of choledochal cyst. According to the Todani classification, it is the type III cyst that opens as a choledochocele into the duodenum.

The clinical picture of cholestatic jaundice and liver dysfunction, with a right upper quadrant palpable mass in a young infant, suggests a possible diagnosis of choledochal cyst. The MRCP (magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatoicography) images shown above in coronal (a) and transverse (b) sections depict type Ia saccular choledochal cysts. The classification system used is called the Todani classification. It is as follows-

Todani classification:

* Type I - saccular dilatation of the whole (Ia) or a segment (Ib) of the common bile duct (CBD)

* Type II - diverticulum from the CBD

* Type III - choledochocele that opens into the duodenum

* Type IV - multiple cysts (both intrahepatic and extrahepatic)

* Type V - multiple cysts that are only intrahepatic (Caroli's disease)

Based on this classification, we can see that type III would be the right answer in this case i.e. the type that opens into the duodenum.

The diagnosis is made initially with a right upper quadrant ultrasound, following which a confirmatory MRCP can be carried out to help in pre-operative planning. 

Treatment is usually surgical with a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy with radical resection of all the biliary tissue. There is a risk of malignant transformation in long-standing disease, so surgical removal is usually recommended.

Pearl PM1614: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.




Pearl PM1539: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

* Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction

* CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS

* MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts

* ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract

* Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done

* PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract

* Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed

* EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: 10. A young boy presents with recurrent cold skin abscesses, recurrent pneumonia with pneumatoceles, and coarse facial features. Laboratory investigations reveal markedly elevated serum IgE levels with eosinophilia. Which genetic defect is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the child presenting with recurrent cold skin abscesses, recurrent pneumonia complicated by pneumatoceles, coarse facial features, and markedly elevated IgE with eosinophilia is characteristic of Job syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome), which is associated with a STAT3 mutation. 

Job syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease caused by a mutation in the STAT3 gene, which impairs the differentiation of TH17 cells and reduces IL-17 production. Since IL-17 is crucial for neutrophil chemotaxis, neutrophil fails to migrate effectively to sites of infection, explaining why the abscesses are cold and lack inflammatory signs. The recurrent lung infections often lead to pneumatoceles, typical of this condition.

Job syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome) is a primary immunodeficiency characterised by a clinical triad of:

* Recurrent cold staphylococcal abscesses (lack warmth/redness due to impaired neutrophil recruitment)

* Recurrent pneumonia (pneumatoceles)

* Eczema-like rash 

The other characteristic features include coarse facies, retained primary teeth, scoliosis and pathological fractures, hyperextensible joints, high IgE, and eosinophilia. 

Other options:

Option A: BTK (Bruton tyrosine kinase) gene mutation causes Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia, which presents with recurrent bacterial infections and absent B cells.

Option C: WASP gene mutation results in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, leading to thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections. 

Option D: FOXP3 mutation causes IPEX syndrome, which manifests with autoimmune enteropathy, endocrinopathy, and dermatitis in infancy.

questions.text:
11. Which of the following is correct regarding Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome?

* Arborizing pattern of connective tissue

* Mutation in the STK11 gene

* Multiple hamartomatous polyps

* Autosomal recessive

* Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium
questions.solution:
The correct statements regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are 1, 2, and 3.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder characterised by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps (Statement 3) and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. The pigmentation is particularly evident on the face, buccal mucosa, hands, feet, and perianal and genital regions. This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years.

Histologic examination shows a characteristic arborising network of connective tissue (Statement 1), smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium, as shown in the image below.



Germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene STK11 (Statement 2) are present in half the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. A complication of Peutz-Jeghers polyps is intussusception, which is occasionally fatal. Peutz-Jegher syndrome is associated with a markedly increased risk of colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Note: Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen in FAP, not Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

Pearl PM1260: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

* Autosomal-dominant disease

* Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

* Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits

* Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract

* Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).

* Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text:
12. What are the indications for elective parathyroidectomy among the given options?

* Renal stones

* Serum Ca > 1mg/dl above the upper limit of normal 

* Age > 50 years 

* BMD T-score > -2.5
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1,2.

Elective parathyroidectomy is indicated in patients with: 

* All symptomatic (renal, bone, neurocognitive, or neuropsychiatric) patients

* Serum calcium > 1mg/dl above the upper limit of normal (Statement 2)

* Age < 50 years (Statement 3 )

* Urine calcium > 400 mg/24 hours

* T-score <-2.5 or a significant reduction in bone mineral density(Statement 4)

* Vertebral compression fracture on spine imaging 

* Impaired renal function, GFR < 60ml/min

* Nephrolithiasis or nephrocalcinosis (Statement 1)

Primary hyperparathyroidism is characterised by excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), most commonly due to a single parathyroid adenoma, followed by hyperplasia or, rarely, carcinoma. Excess PTH  leads to hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and increased bone resorption, resulting in osteopenia, osteoporosis, and fractures. Renal manifestations include nephrolithiasis and nephrocalcinosis, while neuromuscular effects may present as proximal muscle weakness and fatigue. Gastrointestinal and neuropsychiatric symptoms are also common.

Diagnosis is based on elevated serum calcium, with inappropriately high or normal PTH, and low phosphate. First-line investigation is focused neck ultrasound. Sestamibi for parathyroid localisation is the Investigation of choice.

Parathyroidectomy is the only curative treatment for primary hyperparathyroidism. All symptomatic patients need to undergo surgery.

Pearl PM1312: Indications for parathyroidectomy in patients with asymptomatic primary HPT (2013-2014 NIH Consensus Conference Guidelines)

* Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limit of normal

* Renal: 

* Reduction in creatinine clearance by 30%

* 24-h urine calcium >400 mg/day

* Presence of nephrolithiasis or nephrocalcinosis

* Skeletal: 

* Decreased bone mineral density (T score <-2.5)

* Presence of vertebral fracture

* Age <50 years

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text:
14. Match the following types of bias with the best method of prevention:

Bias Method of Prevention
1. Neyman bias a. Use objective records
2. Recall bias b. Select controls within the community   
3. Berksonian bias c. Select incident cases instead of prevalent cases
4. Hawthorne bias d. Blinding of study subjects
questions.solution:
The correct match is 

Bias Method of Prevention
1. Neyman bias c. Select incident cases instead of prevalent cases
2. Recall bias a. Use objective records
3. Berksonian bias b. Select controls within the community   
4. Hawthorne bias d. Blinding of study subjects


Neyman bias is a type of bias that occurs when cases that die early or recover quickly are excluded from a study, leading to a distorted estimation of the association between exposure and outcome. It can be prevented by selecting incident cases instead of prevalent cases. In a prevalent case, the patient has already had the disease for a long time and would likely have progressed, making it likely that they could be excluded from the study. By selecting newly diagnosed(incident) cases, this bias could be prevented.

Recall bias is seen in case-control studies where cases may remember past exposures better than controls, leading to information bias. This can be prevented by using objective records, such as medical records/registries.

Berksonian bias is a selection bias when both cases and controls are chosen from hospitalised patients, since hospitalized patients don't represent the general population. This can be prevented by selecting controls from the general community.

Hawthorne bias is when the study participants change their behaviour simply because they know they’re being observed. This can be prevented by blinding the subjects.

Pearl PM0266: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  


Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: 15. A 19-year-old girl presents with irregular menstrual cycles. An ultrasound image of the ovary is given below. Similar morphology was seen bilaterally. Which of the following hormonal abnormalities can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of irregular cycles and the ultrasound image showing an enlarged ovary with multiple peripherally arranged follicles and central echogenic stroma is suggestive of polycystic ovary syndrome. Elevated dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate can be seen in this condition.

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. For the diagnosis of PCOS, the modified Rotterdam criteria are generally followed. It states that at least two of the three criteria should be present. These criteria are as follows:

* Irregular menstrual cycles characterised by oligomenorrhoea of cycles >35 days apart or <8 menses a year or amenorrhoea or anovulation or infertility

* Hyperandrogenism, which can be clinically detected as hirsutism/acne with a modified Ferriman–Gallwey score of ≥4 to ≥8 or biochemically detected by elevated total or free testosterone. DHEAS (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate) and ANSD (androstenedione) can be considered. 

* Ultrasound finding of enlarged ovaries with ovarian volume of more than 10 mm³ with 12 or more small follicles, each 2-9 mm in size, placed peripherally. ≥20 follicles per ovary in either ovary or ≥10 cm3 ovarian volume

Other hormonal changes that can be seen are:

* Elevated levels of prolactin

* Decreased ratio of estradiol/estrone

* Decreased levels of Sex hormone-binding globulin

* Elevated levels of LH

* LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, so FSH/LH ratio falls.

The new International Evidence-based Guidelines for the assessment and management of polycystic ovary syndrome 2023 supersede the previous USG recommendations of the Rotterdam criteria. According to this guideline, these three factors should be considered accurate ultrasound markers for PCOS in adults:

* Follicle number per ovary (FNPO) ≥ 20 in at least one ovary 

* If an accurate follicle count is not possible: Follicle number per cross-section (FNPS) ≥ 10 in at least one ovary, or 

* Ovarian volume (OV) ≥ 10 mm3

Pearl PM1151: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

* Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.

* LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.

* Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.

* Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)

* Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor

* DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated

* DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour

* Serum SHBG is reduced.

* Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.

* Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance

* Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases

* Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases

* Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)

* 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

* Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Pearl PM1152: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene


Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: 16. Cyclo-developmental type of biological transmission is seen in:
questions.solution:
Filariasis is an example of cyclo-developmental type of biological transmission where the microfilaria undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.



Pearl PM0495: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

* The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.

* E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

* The agent changes in form and in number.

* E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

* The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.

* E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

* Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.

* E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

* The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.

* E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text:
17. A 46-year-old man with a 15-year history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with progressive proteinuria and pedal edema. Renal biopsy reveals the following findings. Which of the following statements are true regarding this patient's condition?

* Amyloid fibrils are composed of immunoglobulin light chains 

* Interleukin-6 contributes to serum amyloid A production

* Associated with chronic inflammatory diseases like inflammatory bowel disease

* Cardiac deposition is common
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 2 and 3.

The given clinical scenario of the patient with the renal biopsy showing amyloid deposits (apple green birefringence under polarised light) suggests a diagnosis of secondary amyloidosis.

Amyloidosis is a disorder linked to various inherited and chronic inflammatory conditions, characterized by extracellular deposition of fibrillar proteins that lead to tissue damage and impaired organ function. Clinically, systemic or generalized amyloidosis is categorized as primary amyloidosis and secondary amyloidosis.

Primary or AL type amyloidosis results from plasma cell dyscrasias such as multiple myeloma, where the amyloid fibrils are composed of immunoglobulin light chains. Cardiac involvement is typical of AL amyloidosis, but rare in secondary or AA type amyloidosis. (Statement 4)

Secondary amyloidosis is a systemic disorder caused by extracellular deposition of amyloid fibrils composed of serum amyloid A (SAA) protein (Statement 1), an acute-phase reactant synthesized by the liver in response to chronic inflammation.

Chronic inflammatory diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn’s, ulcerative colitis) (Statement 3), tuberculosis, and bronchiectasis, are classical associations of secondary amyloidosis. In secondary amyloidosis AA type, the persistent elevation of proinflammatory cytokines, particularly IL-1 and IL-6, stimulates the liver to overproduce SAA (Statement 2). Renal involvement is the common manifestation and typically presents with proteinuria and nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: 18. A 30-year-old veterinarian presents with symptoms of myalgia, fatigue and low-grade fever for the past 10 days. On examination, he had non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy. Sabin-Feldman dye was positive. Which stage of the organism causing this disease is required as the antigen for this test?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of acute acquired toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondii. The Sabin-Feldman dye test requires the tachyzoite stage of the organism as the antigen.

The Sabin-Feldman dye test uses the tachyzoite stage of Toxoplasma gondii as the antigen for detecting specific antibodies in patient serum. Tachyzoites are the rapidly multiplying, invasive form of the parasite responsible for acute infection.

In this test, live tachyzoites are incubated with the patient's serum and complement. If specific antibodies are present, they bind to the tachyzoites and activate complement-mediated lysis of the parasite membranes. This process prevents the tachyzoites from absorbing the alkaline methylene blue dye. A positive test is indicated when fewer than 50% of tachyzoites take up the blue dye, confirming the presence of anti-Toxoplasma antibodies.​

This principle makes the Sabin-Feldman dye test highly sensitive and specific, and it remains the gold standard serological test for toxoplasmosis. The choice of tachyzoites is critical because other stages, like sporozoites or bradyzoites, do not exhibit the same susceptibility to complement lysis and dye uptake.

Given below is the life cycle of toxoplasmosis infection:



Other options:

​​Option A: Sporozoites are found within sporulated oocysts shed by cats; sporozoites are involved in transmission, not diagnosis, and are not present in human tissues during infection.

Option B: Oocyst is the environmentally resistant form excreted by cats; it plays a role in transmission but is not used in serological tests as it lacks relevance to human immune response.

Option D: Bradyzoites are present in tissue cysts during chronic infection; they are less antigenic and not ideal for detecting early immune responses in acute toxoplasmosis.

questions.text:
19. Assertion: Propionic acid spray is used to control Bagassosis in sugarcane factories.
Reason: It prevents fungal growth by reducing the moisture content of bagasse.

choices.text: Both assertion & reason are correct, and reason is the correct explanation for assertion
Both assertion & reason are correct, but reason is not the correct explanation for assertion
Assertion is true, reason is false
Assertion is false, reason is true

questions.solution:
The assertion is true, and the reason is false.

Propionic acid (2%) is indeed sprayed to control the growth of thermophilic actinomycetes in sugarcane bagasse, preventing Bagassosis.

The statement incorrectly claims that it works by reducing moisture content. It actually works as a fungicidal agent, and the risk of Bagassosis increases when the moisture is low, because spores become airborne.

Bagassosis is a classic example of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, characterised by cough, dyspnea, hemoptysis, restrictive pattern on Pulmonary Function Test, and mottled lung opacities on X-ray. Prevention involves maintaining high moisture content in bagasse(20%), spraying with 2% propionic acid, enclosed systems, dust suppression methods, and personal protective equipment, and regular medical check-ups.

questions.text:
20. A 45-year-old patient with moderate-to-severe asthma and chronic rhinosinusitis is started on a biologic that blocks the IL-4 receptor α. After treatment, the patient shows reduced exacerbations and improved lung function. Which drug was most likely used?

IL-4: Interleukin -4
questions.solution:
The drug most likely used is Dupilumab, a monoclonal antibody that blocks the IL-4 receptor α (IL-4Rα), inhibiting the signaling of both IL-4 and IL-13 cytokines.

This blockade reduces IgE synthesis and eosinophilic inflammation, leading to decreased asthma exacerbations and improved lung function in patients with moderate-to-severe asthma. Additionally, dupilumab is effective in treating comorbid conditions such as chronic rhinosinusitis, making it the preferred biologic in this clinical scenario.

Other options

Option A: Mepolizumab, an inhibitor of IL-5, inhibits the activation and development of eosinophils and is used in the treatment of asthma.

Option C: Omalizumab binds to IgE and inhibits its attachment to FcεRI. This prevents the activation of IgE and release of histamines, aiding in the treatment of asthma.

Option D: Benralizumab binds to IL-5Rα, responsible for antibody-mediated cell-mediated cytotoxicity. The binding of benralizumab leads to depletion of eosinophils and basophils, thus improving asthma.

questions.text:
21. A patient presents with complaints of easy fatiguability, weakness, and joint pain. On further questioning, he says that he was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease 1 year back and is on treatment for the same since then. His blood work results are given below. The presenting features of this patient are caused by the adverse effect of which of the following drugs?

* Hemoglobin - 10.5 gm/dL

* Total leukocyte count- 7.6 x 103 /microL

* Platelets - 350000 /microL

* RBC - 3.23 x 106 /microL

* Peripheral smear: Macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of an adverse effect of chronic treatment with omeprazole. It is associated with decreased vitamin B12 absorption, thus leading to megaloblastic anemia in this patient.

Other side effects of using proton-pump inhibitors (PPI) for long-term care include the following: 

* Increased susceptibility to infections like hospital-acquired pneumonia and Clostridium difficile infection (pseudomembranous enterocolitis). 

* Increased risk of bone fracture due to reduced calcium absorption.

* It is also associated with the risk of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in patients with ascites. 

Omeprazole serves as both substrate and inhibitor for CYP2C19. Thus, omeprazole may inhibit the activation of clopidogrel and decrease its antiplatelet action.

Other options:

Option A: Misoprostol produces diarrhea, with or without cramps. It can also cause clinical exacerbations of inflammatory bowel disease.

Option B: The most common side effect of sucralfate is constipation. It should be avoided in patients with renal failure who are at risk of aluminum overload.

Option D: H2 receptor antagonists like cimetidine produces side effects like diarrhea, headache, drowsiness, fatigue, muscular pain, constipation, and gynecomastia.

questions.text: 22. A 35-year-old female patient came with complaints of her hands turning very pale on exposure to cold for one month. The skin on her face and fingers is thickened and tight, and she has dilated capillaries over her face. She has a history of GERD. On investigation, she was found to have the following immunofluorescence pattern. Which of the following antibodies is most specific to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario featuring the Raynaud phenomenon, GERD, telangiectasias and tightening of the skin in the face and hands is suggestive of CREST syndrome/ limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, and anti-centromere antibodies are most specific for this disease. 

CREST syndrome consists of the following:

* Calcinosis cutis

* Raynaud’s phenomenon

* Esophageal dysmotility

* Sclerodactyly

* Telangiectasia

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a chronic autoimmune disease. Progressive fibrosis due to the deposition of extracellular matrix components in different tissues and organs is the prominent feature of SSc. The characteristic features of SSc are vascular damage, inflammation, and the presence of specific autoantibodies. 

SSc is classified into two based on the extent of skin involvement.

* Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis / CREST syndrome

* Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), fibrosis in the skin of acral parts of the body, like the face and limbs (distal to elbow and knee), takes place. Skin fibrosis in limited type has a slow progression, but microcirculation disturbances like Raynaud's phenomenon start long before the skin symptoms and are associated with the involvement of the lungs and esophagus.  Since it has late and slow organ involvement, it is associated with a good prognosis with a 10-year survival of over 90%. 

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are present in 90 - 95% of cases with SSc. Autoantibodies specific to limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis include,

* Anti- centromere

* Anti-Th/To

* Anti-U1-RNP

* Anti-hUBF

Management is based on disease-modifying and organ-specific drugs. For peripheral vasculopathy and digital ulcers, calcium channel blockers like nifedipine amlodipine are used, and for refractory cases, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors are recommended.

Intravenous prostanoids are used for the healing process of digital ulcers and the improvement of microcirculation. The commonly used immunosuppressants for skin fibrosis are methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and mycophenolate mofetil. When these drugs are ineffective or contraindicated, low-dose glucocorticosteroids or rituximab (anti-CD20) are used.

questions.text: 23. A 54-year-old man died within a few days after being diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma. The autopsy revealed a yellowish, spherical neoplasm in one pole of the kidney. The tumor cells invaded the renal vein and extended as a solid column up to the inferior vena cava. Histopathology is shown below. Which of the following subtypes of renal cell carcinoma is most likely?
questions.solution:
The presence of yellow-colored spherical mass associated with tumor cells invading the renal vein is characteristic of clear cell carcinoma. Histopathology shows tumor cells with clear cytoplasm.

Clear-cell carcinoma is the most common type, accounting for 70 to 80% of renal cell cancers. They most likely arise from the proximal tubular epithelium as solitary lesions.

The tumor cells have a rounded or polygonal shape and abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids arranged in a solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular pattern. The lesion appears usually as a solitary, bright yellow-gray-white spherical masses of variable size. The yellow color is due to the prominent lipid accumulations in tumor cells.

Clear-cell RCC has a characteristic tendency to invade the renal vein, where, the tumor may grow as a solid column of cells that can extend up the inferior vena cava, sometimes as far as the right side of the heart.

The given image shows microscopy of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.



Pearl PM2081: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

* Most common type

* Originates from proximal convoluted tubules

* Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 

* Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

* Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules

* Caused by c-met mutation

* Histology shows Psammoma bodies

* Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma

* Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

* Best prognosis

* Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct

* Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy

* Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome

* Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus

* Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

* Worst prognosis

* Originates from collecting tubules

* Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

* Poor prognosis

* Originates from the distal nephron

* Associated with sickle cell trait

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: 24. Which of the following would you not include as a differential diagnosis for a swelling that moves with deglutition?
questions.solution:
A plunging ranula does not move with deglutition.

A ranula is a mucous extravasation cyst originating from the sublingual gland in the floor of the mouth due to either the rupture of the main duct or the rupture of obstructed acini of the sublingual gland. A cervical or plunging ranula occurs when the mucous passes through the mylohyoid muscle diaphragm and enters the neck, presenting as a painless, enlarging neck mass, which does not move with deglutition.

Neck swellings that are attached to the larynx or trachea move with deglutition. Examples include thyroid swellings, thyroglossal cyst (Option A), sub-hyoid bursitis (Option C) and pre- or para-tracheal lymph nodes (Option D).

Other options:

Option A: A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood. Normally, the thyroglossal duct regresses once the thyroid gland has completely descended. If it fails to regress, a thyroglossal duct cyst is formed. It can move with deglutition.

Option C: Inflammation of the bursa just beneath the hyoid bone can lead to subhyoid bursitis. It tends to move with deglutition.

Option D: Paratracheal lymph nodes in the neck are located laterally to the trachea and esophagus, adjacent to the recurrent laryngeal nerve. It is also known to move with deglutition.

Pearl PM1690: Plunging ranula

It is a form of mucous retention cyst that can arise from both sublingual and submandibular salivary glands and presents as dumb-bell-shaped swelling that is soft, fluctuant and painless in the submandibular or submental region of the neck.

* It shows cross fluctuation along the mylohyoid

* Treatment is by removal of the sublingual gland and aspiration of the saliva out from the sac. The cervical approach which was previously used is now contraindicated.

* Conditions with cross fluctuation are :

* Plunging ranula

* Bilocular hydrocele

* Compound palmar ganglion

* Psoas abscess

Note:

The term ‘ranula’ is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland.

questions.text: 25. A patient is being evaluated following a cerebrovascular accident. During the examination, it is seen that the patient's speech is fluent; he is able to understand what is said, but unable to repeat simple phrases. Naming of objects is also impaired. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is conduction aphasia.

Conduction aphasia is a form of aphasia in which both fluency and comprehension remain intact, but the patient shows an isolated impairment in their ability to repeat simple phrases and naming of objects. It occurs due to an injury in the dorsal perisylvian region, which connects Broca’s area with Wernicke’s area.

Other options: 

Option B: Wernicke's area lies in the posterior end of the superior temporal gyrus. It is an important area for word and sentence comprehension. Damage to this area or blockade of the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery causes Wernicke's aphasia. It is a type of fluent aphasia in which comprehension is impaired to the spoken and written words or sentences. The speech is fluent, but contains jargon and neologisms. Therefore, the examiner cannot understand what the patient is speaking. 

Option C: Anomic aphasia is a very mild dysfunction of the language network. Comprehension and repetition are intact, but naming, word finding, and spelling are impaired. It is due to a lesion within the left hemisphere, including the middle and inferior temporal gyri. It can occur due to head trauma, metabolic encephalopathy, and Alzheimer’s disease.

Option D: In Broca's aphasia, the speech is non-fluent, with impaired repetition and naming. However, comprehension is preserved. Broca's area lies in the inferior frontal gyrus. Injury to this area or occlusion of the superior division of the middle cerebral artery leads to Broca's aphasia.

questions.text: 26. A patient sustained a vertebral fracture. On examination, he had bilateral spastic paralysis and bilateral loss of pain, temperature, and a light touch below the level of the lesion. Tactile discrimination, vibratory and proprioceptive sensations were preserved. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is anterior cord syndrome.

Anterior cord syndrome results from ischemia of the anterior spinal artery, and predominantly affects the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord. This can be caused by cord contusion due to vertebral fracture, dislocation, or by a herniated intervertebral disc. The clinical features seen after the period of spinal shock are:

1. Bilateral lower motor neuron paralysis in the segment of the lesion and muscular atrophy. This is caused by damage to neurons in the anterior grey columns and the anterior nerve roots of the same segment.

2. Bilateral spastic paralysis below the level of the lesion due to the involvement of anterior corticospinal tracts on both sides. The spasticity is produced by the interruption of tracts other than the corticospinal tracts.

3. Bilateral loss of pain, temperature, and light touch sensations below the level of the lesion due to anterior and lateral spinothalamic tract involvement on both sides.

4. Tactile discrimination, vibratory and proprioceptive sensations are preserved as the posterior white columns on both sides are intact.

Other options:

Option A: Complete cord transection results in complete loss of all sensation and voluntary movements below the level of the lesion.

* The loss of tactile discrimination,  vibratory and proprioceptive sensations is due to bilateral destruction of the ascending tracts in the posterior white columns.

* The loss of pain, temperature and light touch sensations is due to destruction of the lateral and anterior spinothalamic tracts.

Option B: Central cord syndrome occurs due to damage to the central region of the spinal cord. It commonly occurs due to cord compression between the vertebral body and a bulging ligamentum flavum.

* There is bilateral lower motor neuron paralysis and muscular atrophy in the segment of the lesion.

* Bilateral spasticity, loss of pain, temperature, light touch, and pressure sensations occur below the level of the lesion with characteristic sacral sparing. 

* The lower limb fibers are less affected than the upper limb fibers.

Option D: Brown-Sequard syndrome results from hemisection of the spinal cord due to traumatic injuries. Clinical features include: 

* Ipsilateral lower motor neuron paralysis in the segment of the lesion, muscular atrophy, an ipsilateral band of cutaneous anesthesia in the segment of the lesion

* Ipsilateral loss of tactile discrimination and vibratory and proprioceptive sensations below the level of the lesion.

* Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensations below the level of the lesion and contralateral incomplete loss of tactile sensation below the level of the lesion.

questions.text: 28. A 30-year-old labourer came with complaints of daytime sleepiness with sudden loss of strength. The patient was found to have decreased REM latency in the sleep cycle. What causes this disorder?
questions.solution:
Defective hypocretin (orexin) receptors are seen in narcolepsy, a disorder characterized by decreased REM sleep latency, daytime somnolence, and sudden attacks of loss of muscle tone, often secondary to sensory stimuli (also called cataplexy). 

Narcolepsy is caused due to reduced orexin signalling, either due to the destruction of orexin receptors or due to the loss of hypothalamic neurons producing orexins. Patients with narcolepsy present with cataplexy, hallucinations on sleep onset (hypnagogic hallucinations) or while waking up (hypnopompic hallucinations), and sleep paralysis, i.e, paralysis of muscles on awakening. This is in addition to complaints of disturbed night sleep and excessive daytime sleepiness.

Orexins or hypocretins are produced by the hypothalamus and provide excitatory inputs to the areas of the brain regulated by the hypothalamus. Wakefulness causes maximum activity of orexins, while they stop firing during REM sleep. Thus, defective orexin response leads to narcolepsy (Option A).

Treatment is multifactorial and based on symptoms. Mild disease may be treated with sleep regulation practices, while drugs like modafinil and methylphenidate may aid in promoting wakefulness.

Other options:

Option C: Exaggerated autonomic response may show changes in blood pressure, fatigue, muscle spasms, and dizziness, and is not associated with excessive sleepiness.

Option D: Use of selective H3 antagonists like pitolisant has been seen in the treatment of narcolepsy, as they promote wakefulness.

questions.text: 29. A middle-aged healthy volunteer is given an IV test substance ‘X’ to measure renal clearance. If the plasma concentration of X is 10mg/ml, the urine concentration is 100mg/ml, and the urine flow rate is 1ml/min. Identify which line on the given graph it corresponds to:
questions.solution:
The substance X corresponds to line 3 on the given renal clearance curve.

The given graph shows plasma concentration on the x-axis and clearance on the y-axis. Each line shows how clearance of a particular substance changes with plasma concentration, depending on whether it is filtered, reabsorbed, or secreted.

Renal clearance is defined as the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance per unit time. It is calculated using the formula: C=UV/P​

C​ = renal clearance of substance X (mL/min) U = urine concentration of X (mg/mL) V = urine flow rate (mL/min) P​ = plasma concentration of X (mg/mL)

For the given scenario, calculating the clearance of substance X,

C = (100*1)/10 = 10ml/min.

Clearance of substance X is 10ml/min, which is much less than the GFR (125ml/min). It indicates the substance is undergoing reabsorption. Therefore, it corresponds to Line 3 (Option C).

Line 1 (Option A) - Very high clearance at low plasma levels, decreasing as the plasma concentration increases. It is typical of a substance with active secretion that saturates. E.g., PAH.

Line 2 (Option B) - Clearance is constant and equals GFR, independent of plasma concentration. Typical of inulin.

Line 3 - Very low clearance, much less than GFR. Typical of a substance that is reabsorbed. E.g., glucose, urea.

Line 4 (Option D) - Clearance is initially higher than GFR but becomes constant later, which is seen with creatinine.

questions.text: 30. A 20-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of muscle weakness and headaches. On examination, his blood pressure is markedly elevated. He has a family history of a similar illness. Laboratory findings show hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, low plasma renin activity and low aldosterone. Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism of his condition?

choices.text: A mutation causing increased activity of ENaC in the collecting duct
A mutation causing decreased activity of ENaC in the collecting duct

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis in a patient with a family history of similar illness points toward Liddle’s syndrome. It is caused by a gain-of-function mutation in the ENaC subunit in the collecting duct.

These mutations lead to increased ENaC activity or impaired aldosterone-regulated retrieval from the membrane, resulting in enhanced sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron. Clinically, it presents severe hypertension and hypokalemia, resembling hyperaldosteronism but with low aldosterone levels. 

The metabolic abnormalities in Liddle’s syndrome show no response to spironolactone. Despite being a potassium-sparing diuretic, spironolactone, owing to its action on aldosterone rather than ENaC, is ineffective in Liddle syndrome, but it responds well to amiloride, which directly inhibits ENaC.

Other options:

Option B: A mutation causing decreased activity of ENaC would lead to salt wasting and hypotension, the opposite of the clinical picture.

Option C: Mutation in NaCl co-transporter describes Gitelman's syndrome, hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypotension.

Option D: Loss-of-function mutation of mineralocorticoid receptors would mimic low aldosterone activity in the collecting duct, resulting in salt-wasting, hypotension and hyperkalemia.

questions.text: 31. A child was brought with complaints of diarrhea, step-ladder fever, and palpable spleen. Which of the following is used in the preparation of the vaccine for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The child has features of typhoid, and typhoid vaccines are prepared using the Vi antigen.

Vi vaccine is an injectable vaccine prepared using purified capsular polysaccharide antigen. It is given as a single-dose subcutaneous or intramuscular injection. Boosters can be given after 3 years. 

Ty21a is a live-attenuated vaccine. It is given orally in 3 doses on the 1st, 3rd, and 5th day.

Typhoid caused by Salmonella typhi can present gradually with headache, malaise, anorexia, and abdominal discomfort, with either constipation or diarrhea. Step-ladder pattern of fever, with relative bradycardia and toxemia, are typical findings in enteric fever. Other findings include hepatosplenomegaly and rose spots.

The O antigen is a somatic antigen present in the cell wall, and the H antigen is present on the flagella. H and O agglutinins are measured in the Widal test to detect typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli in the patient's blood.

questions.text: 32. A girl claiming to be more than 18 years old presents to the Obstetrics and Gynecology department with bleeding per vagina. Ultrasound reveals a complete first-trimester abortion. Which of the following can definitely confirm the girl’s claim?

choices.text: Appearance of the ossification centre of 3
Fusion of the ossification centres of 1 and 3
Appearance of the ossification centre of 1
Fusion of the ossification centres of 2 and 4

questions.solution:
Fusion of the body of the pubis (3) occurs at the age of 20 years, and that of the ischial tuberosity (1) occurs between 20–21 years. The fusion of these ossification centres signifies that the girl is more than 20 years old, thus definitely confirming the claim that she is more than 18 years old.

Option C: The ossification centre of the ischial tuberosity (1) appears at the age of 16 years, and hence, this can only confirm that her age is more than 16 years.

Option D: The ossification centres of the greater (4) and the lesser (2) trochanters fuse between 17–18 years. questions.text: 34. A 13-year old boy presented with pain and swelling around his knee. His radiograph is as shown below. He is advised an MRI of his knee. Which of the following finding will be seen on his MRI?
questions.solution:
The given image shows expansile lucency in the upper tibial metaphysis, suggestive of aneurysmal bone cyst. The MRI will show these lesions filled with fluid, giving a 'fluid-fluid levels' appearance.

An aneurysmal bone cyst is a benign, expansile lytic lesion of the metaphysis of the long bones that is comprised of blood-filled cystic spaces. It is more common among adolescents with an equal male: female distribution. They occur more commonly in the metaphysis of the long bones, like the femur, tibia, and humerus. It may occur on the posterior elements of the spine.

Patients usually present with pain and swelling. In cases of spinal involvement, neurologic manifestations can be seen due to nerve root impingement.

A plain radiograph shows an expansile, lytic lesion in the metaphysis. MRI reveals a typical cystic lesion and numerous intralesional septations along with fluid-fluid levels. A biopsy would reveal blood-filled cystic spaces with fibrous septations, which might consist of woven bone.

Curettage and bone grafting are used for management in most cases. Arterial embolization is preferred in cases where curettage is extremely difficult. Low-dose radiation is also effective but is avoided in view of potential malignant transformation.

Other options:

Option A: Skip lesions are typically seen in malignant tumors like osteosarcoma, where lesions can be seen in the marrow on T1-weighted imaging at different levels in one bone.

Option C: Rings and arcs chondroid matrix is seen in tumors of cartilagenous origin, e.g., chondrosarcoma.

Option D: Ground glass matrix is a feature of fibrous dysplasia.

questions.text: 35. A patient with asthma was intubated using ketamine as an induction agent. What premedication will be effective for the prevention of ketamine induced increased salivation?
questions.solution:
For the prevention of ketamine-induced sialorrhea (excessive salivation), anticholinergic drugs such as glycopyrrolate will be effective.

Glycopyrrolate is a quaternary anticholinergic agent commonly used as a premedication to reduce salivary, tracheobronchial, and pharyngeal secretions, making it highly effective in preventing ketamine-induced sialorrhea (excessive salivation). It acts primarily by blocking peripheral muscarinic receptors, and it does not cross the blood-brain barrier significantly, so it limits central side effects such as sedation or delirium.

Ketamine is a dissociative anaesthetic commonly used for anaesthesia induction, analgesia, and emergency airway management. It has a rapid onset, is effective in the maintenance of airway reflexes, and has cardiovascular stimulant effects, making it especially useful in hemodynamically unstable patients.

Ketamine may increase heart rate, blood pressure, and myocardial oxygen demand, making it unsuitable for patients with ischemic heart disease. In the central nervous system, it can cause emergence reactions such as vivid dreams, hallucinations, and delirium, which are more common in adults. 

Respiratory effects include occasional apnea and increased salivation or airway secretions. Ketamine may also raise intracranial pressure, so caution is required in patients with head injuries unless they are mechanically ventilated. Other adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, and increased muscle tone. It is contraindicated in individuals with schizophrenia.

Other options:

Option A: Propofol is an induction agent with sedative and hypnotic properties, but it does not reduce salivation.

Option B: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine used for anxiolysis, sedation, and amnesia as a premedication. It does not affect secretions but can reduce ketamine-induced emergence reactions.

Option D: Beta-blockers are primarily used for cardiovascular management; they have no role in controlling secretions or salivation.

questions.text:
36. Which of the following statements are correct about bisphosphonates?

* Risedronate can be used in hypercalcemia of malignancy.

* Pamidronate causes esophagitis and heartburn.

* Renal function tests are required before starting zoledronate.

* Raloxifene reduces vertebral fractures but not hip fractures, unlike bisphosphonates, which prevent both types of fractures.
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 3, 4.

Risedronate is an oral bisphosphonate and has no role in hypercalcemia of malignancy, which requires rapid-acting IV agents like pamidronate or zoledronate. Oral agents are ineffective in emergencies due to delayed onset.

Pamidronate is given IV, so it does not cause esophagitis or heartburn, which are side effects limited to oral bisphosphonates like alendronate and risedronate. IV agents more commonly cause flu-like symptoms due to cytokine release.

Zoledronate, an IV bisphosphonate, is potentially nephrotoxic; hence, renal function tests are mandatory before initiation. 

Raloxifene reduces vertebral fractures only, while bisphosphonates are effective in preventing both vertebral and non-vertebral (including hip) fractures

Mechanism of Action of Bisphosphonates:

* Induce osteoclast apoptosis

* Inhibits farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase in the mevalonate pathway, disrupting osteoclast function and survival

Side Effects of Bisphosphonates:

* Oral agents: Esophagitis, heartburn

* IV agents: Acute-phase flu-like symptoms

* Other common side effects include hypocalcemia, renal toxicity (especially IV forms), osteonecrosis of the jaw, atypical femur fractures (long-term use), and musculoskeletal pain

37. A health care worker in a PHC is screening pregnant women for risk of preeclampsia using the HDP-Gestosis score. Which among the following risk factors will be given the maximum score?

PHC- Primary Health Care

HDP- Hypertensive Disorders in Pregnancy
questions.solution:
Pregestational diabetes mellitus will be given the maximum score.

The HDP-Gestosis score is a clinical risk assessment tool developed to identify pregnant women at risk for preeclampsia. The score is designed to be a feasible and easy-to-use tool for clinical assessment. It is intended for use by healthcare professionals, including potentially less-skilled workers at a ground level, to screen for and predict pre-eclampsia. 

This score involves all the existing and emerging risk factors for preeclampsia in the pregnant woman. Score 1, 2 and 3 is allotted to each clinical risk factor as per its severity in the development of preeclampsia.  With careful history and assessment of the woman, a total score is obtained time to time. When the total score is ≥3; the pregnant woman should be marked as ‘At risk for Preeclampsia’. Women with a high gestosis score can be monitored more closely and may be recommended to take aspirin to help prevent or reduce the severity of pre-eclampsia. 

The following is the scoring criteria of the Gestosis score based on risk factors :

* A score of 1 is given to:

* Age >35 years and <19 years

* Maternal anaemia

* Obesity (BMI >30)

* Family history of cardiovascular disease

* Primigravida

* Polycystic ovary syndrome

* interval pregnancy interval >7 years

* Conceived with assisted reproductive (IVF/ICSI) treatment

* MAP >85 mm of Hg

* Chronic vascular disease (dyslipidemia)

* Excessive weight gain during pregnancy

* A score of 2 is given to:

* Maternal hypothyroidism

* Family history of pre-eclampsia

* Gestational diabetes mellitus

* Obesity (BMI >35 kg/M2)

* Multifetal pregnancy

* Hypertensive disease during previous pregnancy

* A score of 3 is given to:

* Pregestational diabetes mellitus

* Chronic hypertension

* Mental disorders

* Inherited/acquired thrombophilia

* Maternal chronic kidney disease

* Autoimmune disease 

* Pregnancy with assisted reproductive treatment

questions.text: 38. An infant is brought with a history of multiple fractures, anemia, cranial nerve defects, hepatosplenomegaly along with a history of repeated infections. Genetic workup reveals defects in the gene for the enzyme carbonic anhydrase 2 with the pedigree analysis suggestive of autosomally recessive inheritance. What is the likely diagnosis in this infant?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is osteopetrosis (Albers-Schonberg disease). which is due to the autosomal recessive defect in the gene for the enzyme carbonic anhydrase 2

Carbonic anhydrase II is required by osteoclasts and renal tubular cells to generate protons from carbon dioxide and water (acidification). The absence of CA2 prevents osteoclasts from acidifying the resorption pit and dissolution of calcium hydroxyapatite within the bone matrix and also blocks the acidification of urine by the renal tubular cells. This leads to reduced bone resorption and diffuse symmetric skeletal sclerosis.

Due to deficient osteoclast activity, bones involved by osteopetrosis lack a medullary canal, and the ends of long bones are bulbous (Erlenmeyer flask deformity). The neural foramina are small and compress the exiting nerves, leading to cranial nerve palsies. Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis leads to leukopenia and prominent hepatosplenomegaly.

Osteopetrosis can be successfully treated with hematopoietic stem cell transplantation and recombinant human interferon-gamma.

Other Options:

Option A: Osteoporosis is characterised by diffuse reduction in the bone density due to a decrease in the bone mass. It is an asymptomatic disorder unless complications occur. Loss of bone mass leads to loss of strength, so that a trivial trauma is sufficient to cause a fracture.

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta is a disease of the mesodermal tissue with abnormal or deficient collagen. Blue sclera, dentinogenesis imperfecta, generalised osteoporosis, multiple fractures or bowing of the long bones is seen. Multiple wormian bones around the base of skull are a major finding.

Option D: Vrolik's syndrome is another name for Osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: 39. A 78-year-old man with hormone-refractory prostatic carcinoma was treated with paclitaxel. Which phase of the cell cycle does the drug act on?
questions.solution:
Paclitaxel, which acts on the M-phase of the cell cycle, represented by '4', is used in hormone-refractory prostate cancer.

Paclitaxel, a taxane drug, binds to beta-tubulin, stabilizing the microtubules and causing the tubulin-microtubule dynamic disequilibrium. This is due to the disruption of the reorganization of the microtubule network, which is needed for mitosis.

It can be used in chemotherapy regimens for small-cell lung cancer, esophageal adenocarcinoma, and advanced cases of head and neck cancer, in addition to urinary, hormone-refractory prostate cancer, and AIDS related Kaposi sarcoma.

Toxic effects include granulocytopenia due to reversible suppression of myeloid cells, peripheral neuropathy, nausea, chest pain, arthralgia, and mucositis. Dexamethasone, H1, and H2 antihistamines are prescribed before the administration of paclitaxel to prevent acute anaphylactoid reactions.

questions.text: 40. You are working as a junior resident in the ENT department when a patient brings the following X-Ray image. Which of the following structures is best visualized in this view?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a radiographic image captured in the occipitofrontal view or Caldwell view. This is the best view for visualizing the frontal sinus.

Caldwell's view is taken with the nose and forehead are touching the x-ray film. The X-ray beam is projected caudally at a 15-20 degree angle.

Structures seen in Caldwell's view are:

* Frontal sinuses (seen best)

* Ethmoid sinuses

* Maxillary sinuses

* Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone

* Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea

* Superior orbital fissure

* Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

The image below shows the projection of the x-ray beams in relation to the position of the head.



The image below shows the sinuses seen in the Caldwell view:



The best view for visualizing the maxillary sinus is Waters' view. It is taken in such a way that nose and chin of the patient touch the film while an X-ray beam is projected from behind. Waters’ view with an open mouth is preferred as it also shows sphenoid sinus.

The submentovertical (basal) view is best suited for visualizing the sphenoid sinus. It is taken when the vertex near the X-ray film and the X-ray beam is projected at right angles to the film from the submental area. The sphenoid, posterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses are seen best in that order.
