167. During her initial ANC visit to a resource-poor rural PHC, a pregnant woman tests reactive for syphilis using a Dual RDT. What is the next best step in management?

Dual RDT - Dual HIV/syphilis rapid diagnostic test Antenatal care - ANC

choices.text: Wait for confirmatory RPR/VDRL before treatment
Administer Inj. Benzathine Penicillin G 2.4 million units IM immediately
Administer 3 weekly doses of Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units immediately

questions.solution:
In a pregnant woman who tests reactive for syphilis by a dual RDT, as per national guidelines, Inj. Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units IM must be given immediately,  without waiting for confirmation.

All pregnant women who test positive for RPR/VDRL should receive complete treatment with Injection Benzathine penicillin G, administered as three doses of 2.4 million units IM each at a one-week interval (Option C).

Universal screening for syphilis and HIV is recommended for all pregnant women at their first ANC visit. Those testing reactive for syphilis (via Dual RDT or RPR/VDRL) should immediately receive a first on-spot dose of injection benzathine penicillin G (BPG) at the nearest treatment facility, without awaiting confirmation. Confirmatory testing (RPR/VDRL or TPHA/TPELISA) should not delay this initial dose. The National Programme mandates a "Test & Treat" policy, ensuring all pregnant women screening positive receive at least one on-spot dose of BPG. However, complete treatment for RPR/VDRL-positive pregnant women involves three doses of 2.4 million units IM Inj. Benzathine Penicillin G, administered weekly.

questions.text: 168. A 45-year-old man presents after trauma with leg pain, swelling, foul-smelling discharge, and crepitus. When a sample from the wound was cultured on egg yolk agar, the given reaction was observed. Identify the test and the mechanism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a man presenting with leg pain, swelling, foul-smelling discharge, and crepitus after trauma represents gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens, which shows a positive Nagler reaction when cultured on egg yolk agar, and it is based on neutralisation.

Neutralisation tests utilise anti-toxins/antibodies to neutralise the toxin produced by an organism. The alpha-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on an egg yolk medium with the C. perfringens antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralisation of alpha-toxin.



Other examples of neutralisation tests are:

* Plaque inhibition test: Neutralisation of bacteriophages 

* Schick test: Neutralisation of diphtheria toxin by antitoxin

* Anti-Streptolysin O test: For beta-hemolytic streptococci 

Elek's test is an in vitro precipitation (immunodiffusion) test used to determine whether or not a strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae is toxigenic. In Elek’s gel precipitation test, a toxigenic strain produces arrowhead-shaped lines of precipitation where diphtheria toxin and antitoxin meet in optimal concentrations. Non-toxigenic strains show no precipitate, indicating the absence of toxin production.

questions.text: 169. Which of the following are not included among the minor criteria of the modified Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii

questions.solution:
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii is one of the major criteria of modified Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. All other options are minor criteria.

Infective endocarditis is associated with bacterial or fungal infection of the valvular or endocardial surface of the heart. The definitive diagnosis can only be established by histological and microbiological examinations of the vegetation.

However, a diagnostic schema called, modified Duke criteria, is usually used for diagnosis. The criteria are based on clinical, laboratory, and echocardiographic findings commonly encountered in patients with endocarditis, as described below.

The diagnosis is made based on the presence of

* Two major criteria, or

* One major and three minor criteria, or

* Five minor criteria.

Pearl PM2026: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

* Pathologic criteria

* Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.



Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

* Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR

* If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

170. You are posted in the endocrinology department, where two patients, A and B, are being investigated for adrenal insufficiency. Cosyntropin test was positive in each case. Which of the following investigations is not useful for the diagnosis in the respective cases?

Patient A: A 42-year-old man with progressive fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, and low blood pressure.

Patient B: A 50-year-old woman with progressive fatigue, weight loss, and alabaster coloured pale skin.

VLCFA - Very long chain fatty acids

choices.text: CT scan of the suprarenal glands in A

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes patient A and patient B with primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency, respectively. Autoantibodies in B are not useful for the diagnosis in case of patient B.

Patient A is a case of primary adrenal insufficiency, which presents with progressive fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, and low blood pressure. Hyperpigmentation is due to excess ACTH derived from a precursor hormone called pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC), which serves as the precursor for the synthesis of melanocyte-stimulating hormone.

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) is most commonly due to autoimmune adrenalitis. Therefore, autoantibodies are useful in the investigation of patient A. Other causes of Addison's disease include destruction of the adrenal gland due to infections such as TB, haemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome due to meningococcemia), or tumour infiltration, for which a CT scan of the suprarenal glands is useful (option D). X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy can also present with primary adrenal insufficiency, which can be diagnosed by elevated plasma VLCFA levels (option B).

Patient B is a case of secondary adrenal insufficiency, which presents with progressive fatigue, weight loss, and alabaster coloured pale skin. Secondary adrenal insufficiency presents with skin paleness due to the relatively lower stimulation of the melanocytes due to the deficiency of ACTH. Secondary adrenal insufficiency occurs due to hypothalamic-pituitary axis dysfunction. This can include iatrogenic suppression due to chronic therapy with glucocorticoids or because of pituitary and hypothalamic tumours (MRI pituitary - option A).

Primary and secondary adrenal insufficiencies can be differentiated biochemically:

Primary adrenal insufficiency Secondary adrenal insufficiency
Serum ACTH: high Serum ACTH: low
Plasma renin: high (minerocorticoid deficiency also present, since the adrenal gland itself is not functioning) Plasma renin: normal (adrenal gland itself is functional and can be regulated by the renin-angiotensin system)
Plasma aldosterone: low Plasma aldosterone: normal

questions.text:
171. A scientist conducts a study on the effect of various substances on the MMC. Which of the following statements regarding agents that influence gastric phase III contractions are correct?

* Motilin induces gastric phase III contractions by acting directly on motilin receptors in the GI tract.

* Erythromycin stimulates MMC activity by improving gastric flora balance and secondarily enhancing motility.

* Exogenously administered Ghrelin influences MMC in a manner similar to motilin and can induce premature gastric phase III contractions.

* Somatostatin inhibits MMC phase III activity by suppressing motilin secretion.

MMC - Migrating Motor Complex
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1, 3, 4.

Motilin induces gastric phase III contractions by acting directly on motilin receptors in the GI tract (Statement 1). It acts on smooth muscle cells and enteric neurons in the gastric antrum and duodenum to initiate the sweeping Phase III activity. Erythromycin stimulates MMC activity by improving gastric flora balance and secondarily enhancing motility(Statement 2) is an incorrect statement. Erythromycin enhances upper GI motility by increasing lower oesophageal sphincter pressure and promoting contractions in the stomach and small intestine.

Exogenously administered Ghrelin influences MMC in a manner similar to motilin and can induce premature gastric phase III contractions (Statement 3). Ghrelin also acts as a potent prokinetic agent. Somatostatin inhibits MMC phase III activity by suppressing motilin secretion (Statement 4). It is a broad inhibitory peptide, and by inhibiting motilin secretion, somatostatin removes the primary trigger for the MMC.

The MMC is a cyclical pattern of electromechanical activity that occurs during fasting in the GI tract. MMC activity is essential for gut cleansing between meals and is suppressed upon food intake. Each cycle lasts approximately 90–120 minutes and is divided into three phases:



* Phase I (Quiescent): Minimal to no contractions.

* Phase II (Irregular Activity): Irregular, low-amplitude contractions.

* Phase III (Housekeeper Wave): A short (~10-minute) burst of intense, high-frequency contractions. During this phase, the pylorus and ileocecal valve open fully, where large indigestible materials are cleared from the stomach and small intestine.

questions.text: 172. Which of the following pathways is the main source of energy for the heart?
questions.solution:
Beta oxidation is the main source of energy for the heart.

The adult heart needs a continuous supply of ATP. In the fasting and fed states, the heart mainly uses free fatty acids as the chief substrate. This is because the heart has high mitochondrial density, and the beta oxidation pathway produces a larger amount of ATP as compared to other substrates.

The metabolism of fatty acids by beta-oxidation has also been known to influence the pathophysiology of cardiac diseases. The decreased beta oxidation in a failing, ischemic heart and increased beta oxidation and uptake of fatty acids in metabolic syndrome, diabetes, and obesity have been known to influence the course of cardiac diseases.

questions.text: 173. A middle-aged woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the epiploic foramen and was worried she might have injured the structures around it. All are true about the boundaries of the epiploic foramen except:

choices.text: Posteriorly -  Aorta and origin of celiac trunk

questions.solution:
Posterior relation of epiploic foramen does not include aorta and origin of celiac trunk.

Epiploic foramen is posteriorly related to inferior vena cava, right suprarenal gland, and body of T12 vertebra. Commencement of abdominal aorta and celiac trunk forms posterior relation of the lesser sac and not of Epiploic foramen. 

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac) is a short vertical slit situated behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac.

* Posterior – Body of T12 vertebra, Inferior vena cava, right adrenal gland.

* Superior – Caudate lobe of the liver.

* Inferior – First part of the duodenum and the horizontal part of the hepatic artery.

questions.text:
174. Assertion: A lesion in the nucleus tractus solitarius abolishes reflex bradycardia in response to acute hypertension.
Reason: Baroreceptor afferents project directly to the vasomotor centre in the medulla.

choices.text: Both assertion & reason are correct, and reason is the correct explanation for assertion
Both assertion & reason are correct, but reason is not the correct explanation for assertion
Assertion is true, reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
The correct statement is that the assertion is true, but the reason is false.

A lesion in the nucleus tractus solitarius abolishes reflex bradycardia in response to acute hypertension, which is a true statement. The Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS) in the dorsal medulla is the first central relay station for afferents from baroreceptors (carried via cranial nerves IX and X) and chemoreceptors. In response to acute hypertension, baroreceptors increase their firing; signals are relayed to the NTS, which inhibits the vasomotor centre (↓ sympathetic tone → vasodilation) and stimulates vagal nuclei (↑ parasympathetic tone → bradycardia). Therefore, a lesion of the NTS interrupts this reflex arc, abolishing reflex bradycardia and vasodilation, validating the assertion.

Baroreceptor afferents project directly to the vasomotor centre in the medulla is a false statement, as baroreceptors first synapse in the NTS, which then modulates downstream autonomic centres.

questions.text: 175. A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fever, agitation, palpitations, and vomiting. Her blood pressure is 140/60 mmHg, pulse 160/min, and temperature 104°F. She is disoriented and diaphoretic. She has a known history of Graves’ disease, but stopped her medications 2 weeks ago. Which of the following is not used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of thyrotoxic crisis secondary to untreated Graves’ disease. Atropine, an anticholinergic agent, is not used in this condition as it can worsen the tachycardia, which is a cardinal feature of thyrotoxic crisis.

Atropine (option B), being an anticholinergic, will worsen tachycardia. It works by blocking M2 receptors in the SA node, thereby reducing vagal tone and increasing heart rate. It shortens the AV node's refractory period, enhancing conduction and reducing the P-R interval, especially when vagal tone is high.

Propylthiouracil (option D) is the antithyroid DOC (drug of choice) in thyrotoxic crisis. It inhibits thyroid hormone production and limits the peripheral conversion of T4 to the more active T3. Nonselective β-blockers like propranolol provide significant symptom relief and, at higher doses, inhibit the conversion of T4 to T3. Lugol’s iodine or iodine-based contrast agents help block T3/T4 release and reduce T4-to-T3 conversion. 

Hydrocortisone(option C) plays a supportive role in thyrotoxic crisis by providing adrenal support, blunting the peripheral conversion of T4 to the more active T3, and helping stabilise the acute phase before transitioning to oral therapy like prednisolone. Cholestyramine (option A) is also used in management, as it helps by sequestering thyroid hormones.

Pearl PM0784: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

* When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy

* Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications

* Stress

* Infection

* Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery

* Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis

* Acute iodine load

* Amiodarone administration 

* Exposure to iodinated contrast agents

Clinical features:

* Fever

* Tachycardia

* Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)

* GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)

* Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

177. A 25-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed road traffic accident. He is hypotensive, tachycardic, and suspected to be in hemorrhagic shock. The attending senior instructs you to initiate damage control resuscitation immediately. Which of the following is not a component of damage control resuscitation?

PRBC-Packed Red Blood Cells
questions.solution:
A young trauma patient in haemorrhagic shock should be managed according to Damage Control Resuscitation (DCR) principles, which do not involve empirical use of vasopressors.

DCR aims to prevent and correct the “lethal triad” of trauma, hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy, which is often precipitated by uncontrolled bleeding and worsened by traditional fluid resuscitation strategies.

Components of damage control resuscitation include minimal use of crystalloid, like Ringer's lactate. Crystalloids are considered to be the primary cause of the inflammatory process after traumatic hemorrhagic shock. Abdominal compartment syndrome is also found to be directly associated with the volume of crystalloid infused. Damage control/hemostatic resuscitation was introduced to combat this glitch. It focuses on rapid control of bleeding. 

Components of damage control or hemostatic resuscitation:

* Permissive hypotension (option B) until definitive surgical control - minimises the use of acellular fluids and potential disruption of natural clot formation 

* Minimise the usage of crystalloids (Option C)

* Early use of blood products - whole blood first, followed by the component therapy using packed red blood cells (option D), Fresh frozen plasma, and platelets in the ratio of 1:1:1 

*  Initial use of 5% hypertonic saline reduces the total volume of crystalloids needed

* Using drugs like recombinant factor VIIA, prothrombin complex concentrates, tranexamic acid, etc., to control bleeding and treat coagulopathy

   This protocol has massively reduced the incidence of ICU admissions and ARDS.

Vasopressors may be used carefully in some refractory cases, but are not used empirically or routinely early in hemorrhagic shock because they can worsen tissue perfusion or mask ongoing bleeding

178. A 60-year-old chronic alcoholic presented to the ED with acute incoherent speech starting 3 hours prior. History includes UGI scopy for melena 2 weeks ago and laparoscopic hernia surgery 2 months ago. A head CT scan was performed, and tenecteplase was contraindicated. Why was it contraindicated?

Vitals: BP - 160/94mmHg Pulse - 78 beats/min Respiratory rate - 15 breaths/min

UGI - Upper gastrointestinal

choices.text: Due to CT findings as shown above
UGI scopy for melena 2 weeks back

questions.solution:
History of melena 2 weeks back, suggestive of gastrointestinal bleeding (in the past 21 days), is a contraindication for the administration of tenecteplase in this patient. 

The clinical vignette with an acute history of incoherent speech and a hyperdense sign (red arrow) in the Middle cerebral artery (MCA), suggestive of an embolus in the MCA, is indicative of early ischemic stroke. Since the patient presented in the window period (within 4.5 hours), intravenous thrombolysis can be carried out using recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) (0.9mg/kg IV, 10% total dose as bolus, remaining by slow infusion over 60 minutes) or tenecteplase (0.25mg/kg IV over 5 seconds), after evaluating the indications and contraindications.

questions.text: 179. Postmortem examination of a body reveals copious froth from the mouth, nose, and air passages. There is hemorrhage into the middle ears, subpleural hemorrhages at the base of the lungs, and emphysema aquosum, prompting suspicion of drowning. Which of the following findings would strongly suggest that the person was alive when he drowned?
questions.solution:
Cadaveric spasm strongly indicates that the person was alive when he drowned because it indicates the struggle of the person for his life. 

Weeds, gravel, grass, sticks, twigs, and leaves present in the water may be firmly grasped in the hands due to cadaveric spasms. 

Autopsy findings in drowning:

* Froth in the air passages - The most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.

* Waterlogging of the lung - Frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed and from the cut surfaces when they are sectioned with a knife. But the absence of waterlogging by no means excludes true drowning (e.g. dry drowning).

* Emphysema aqueosum - Overinflation of the lungs

* Paltauf’s spots - Subpleural hemorrhages that probably reflect hemolysis within intra-alveolar hemorrhages

* Dilation of the right heart and great veins - This is a very subjective and non-specific finding.

* Foreign material in the stomach - The stomach may contain watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed, and sand. This is also not a finding that can diagnose drowning.

* Hemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - This has been postulated as a positive sign of drowning, it is a non-specific finding.

* Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses 

Note - The autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. 

Other options:

Option B: Cutis anserina (goose-skin or goose-flesh), in which the skin has a granular and puckered appearance can be seen on the anterior surfaces of the body, especially on the thighs.  It is produced by the spasm of the erector pilae muscles, attached to each hair follicle, and can occur in the living when the skin comes in contact with cold water. It can occur on submersion of the body in cold water immediately after death, while the muscles were still warm and irritable. It can also be produced by rigor mortis of the erector muscles.

Option C: The presence of sand, fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, and other foreign material in the nostrils or upper airways is not a sign of antemortem drowning.

Option D: Washerwoman’s hands is a specific change that is seen in the skin of the palm and sole, which comprises of wrinkled, swollen, whitish sodden appearance of hands or feet. It can also be considered as water maceration of the skin of the hand, due to the absorption of water into the outer layers of the skin. Although the changes in washerwomen’s hands and feet are usually seen in dead bodies recovered from the water, this cannot be considered a sign of antemortem drowning.

questions.text:
180. The graph below shows height-for-age curves of four general causes of proportional short stature. Match the following curves with the likely conditions that might correspond to them

 

* A child whose bone age is less than the chronological age and the growth velocity is normal.

* A child with a pituitary tumor presenting with growth hormone deficiency.

* A child diagnosed with Down's syndrome.

* A child with a family history of short stature.
questions.solution:
The given graph shows four height-for-age curves of different causes of short stature.

The correct match is:

Conditions Curve
A. A child whose bone age is less than the chronological age. Curve 2
B. A child with a pituitary tumor presenting with growth hormone deficiency. Curve 1
C. A child diagnosed with Down's syndrome. Curve 4
D. A child with a family history of short stature. Curve 3


Short stature can be defined as growth below the expected genetic potential or below -2 SD for age and sex. If a child's stature is less than -3 SD below the average for their age and gender, it is more likely to indicate pathological short stature. A child's height between -2 and -3 SD is more likely due to physiological, i.e. familial or constitutional short stature.

To assess children under 2 years old, supine length should be measured using an infantometer. For older children, height should be measured using a stadiometer.

Curve 1 shows that the growth curve initially follows the average pattern but then deviates below the mean curve and gradually tapers off. This represents postnatal onset pathologic short stature. The onset of this condition can be due to factors like undernutrition, systemic illness, or endocrine issues such as growth hormone deficiency or hypothyroidism.

Curve 2 shows that the growth decreases near the end of infancy, runs parallel through middle childhood, and accelerates toward the end of adulthood with the achievement of normal adult height. This represents the constitutional growth delay where the onset of puberty and adolescent growth spurt is also delayed. Bone age is lower than chronological age and corresponds to the height age.

Curve 3 shows that the growth runs parallel to and just below the mean curve from early childhood till adulthood. The child has a family history of short stature. Familial short stature is characterized by both the infant and the parents being small in stature. In this case, the bone age aligns with the chronological age, and the projected adult height is below average. The height of the parents has a significant impact on the child's height. Mid-parental height (MPH) provides a rough estimation of the child's genetically determined potential height.

Curve 4 shows that the growth is decreased since birth and remains below the mean curve. The growth is less than -2 SD while reaching adulthood. This represents the prenatal onset of pathological short stature. In congenital pathologic short stature, an infant may or may not be born small, but growth gradually tapers throughout infancy. Causes include chromosome or genetic abnormalities like Turner syndrome, skeletal dysplasia, trisomy 21, perinatal infection, extreme prematurity, and teratogens.

questions.text: 181. A 20-year-old college student presents with a persistent dry cough and low-grade fever for 10 days. The chest X-ray shows patchy infiltrates. Culture shows the following findings. Which of the following statements is true about this organism?

choices.text: Presence of a peptidoglycan cell wall
Requires cholesterol supplementation for in vitro growth

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette, along with the culture showing fried egg colonies, points to a diagnosis of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. This organism requires cholesterol supplementation for its in vitro growth.

Mycoplasma is the smallest free-living organism and lacks a cell wall (Option A) because of which it does not demonstrate a true Gram stain pattern (Option D); it is resistant to β-lactams (Option B). M. pneumoniae is the most common cause of primary atypical pneumonia, characterized by insidious onset with low-grade fever, malaise, and persistent dry cough, and chest examination reveals only mild crackles, while the x-ray shows patchy, diffuse interstitial infiltrates.

Upper respiratory tract infection (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) and pneumonia are common pulmonary manifestations. It can also present with extrapulmonary manifestations, including erythema multiforme/Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), cold agglutinin disease, Guillain-Barré syndrome, transverse myelitis, arthritis, myocarditis, pericarditis, and encephalitis.

Investigations include the presence of cold agglutinins (IgM antibodies against the I antigen of RBCs). Culture shows a typical fried egg appearance on PPLO agar. These colonies can be examined under a hand lens or by the use of a special stain such as Diene's stain. The diagnosis is made by serology or by PCR. Macrolides are the most effective drug for management.

questions.text:
182. Which of the following statements regarding cannabis preparations are correct?

* The highest concentration of tetrahydrocannabinol is present in hash oil.

* Bhang consists of dried leaves and shoots of cannabis.

* Ganja is prepared from the flowering tops of the male cannabis plant.

* Charas is a resinous exudate from leaves, flowers, and stems.
questions.solution:
The correct statements regarding cannabis preparations are 1, 2, and 4.

Cannabis is the most widely misused illicit drug in India. The active compounds of cannabis are found in its resin. The main components include cannabinol, which has no significant effects, and cannabidiol, which is also inactive. However, when heated, cannabidiol is partially transformed into tetrahydrocannabinols (THC) — powerful isomers responsible for cannabis’s psychoactive effects.

Various preparations of cannabis are as follows:

* Charas: It is a resinous exudate from leaves, flowers, and stems (statement 4). It is combined with tobacco and smoked using a pipe.

* Bhang: It consists of dried leaves and shoots of cannabis (statement 2), and it is the least potent form of cannabis and is used as a beverage.

* Ganja: It is prepared from the flowering tops of the female cannabis plant (statement 3).

* Hash oil: Cannabis concentrate is created through multiple extraction processes, resulting in a thick, dark liquid known as hash oil. The highest concentration of THC is present in hash oil (statement 1).

* Majoon: A sweet prepared from bhang.

 The given image below shows cannabis:



The clinical features of cannabis are as follows:

* Low dose: Mild effects such as euphoria, relaxation, enhanced sensory perception, and slight disorientation.

* Moderate dose: Short-term memory issues, disrupted thinking, difficulty focusing, and a sense of unfamiliarity.

* High dose: Altered body perception, a feeling of detachment from oneself (depersonalization), and significant sensory distortions.

Pearl PM0871: Cannabis Forms

* Majoon: Sweet prepared from bhang

* Ganja: Prepared from flower tops of female plant and smoked

* Charas: Most potent; resin exudate from leaves and stems that's smoked

questions.text: 183. The given image depicts Brown-Sequard syndrome. The part marked as 1 is the site of the lesion. Which of the following is inappropriately matched?
questions.solution:
The part marked 3 is incorrectly matched. Discriminative touch (also known as fine touch) is lost on the ipsilateral side of the lesion in Brown Sequard syndrome.

The part marked as 1 is the site of the lesion, at which hemisection of the cord is seen.

The part marked as 2 is the ipsilateral side of the lesion, which has the following features.

* Loss of proprioception and vibration

* Loss of discriminative touch

* Weakness and spastic type of paralysis in certain muscle groups

The part marked as 3 is the contralateral side of the lesion and exhibits the following features

* Loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion

questions.text: 184. You work under a research scientist who is working on determining the association of mesothelioma with a compound, labeled compound X. He uses a test whose steps are shown in the image below to determine the mutagenic effect and potential carcinogenicity of compound X. What is this test that he has used?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Ames test.

Ames test is a widely used biological assay to assess the mutagenic potential of chemical compounds. It uses bacteria to test if the given chemical can cause mutations in the test organism's DNA. A positive test indicates that the chemical is mutagenic and therefore may act as a carcinogen because cancer is often linked to mutation.

The Ames test uses the principle of flocculation. Ames test does not determine the nature of carcinogenesis. The rationale of the test is that greater than 90% of all chemical mutagens are carcinogenic in subsequent animal tests. The bacterium used in the test is a strain of Salmonella typhimurium that carries a defective (mutant) gene making it unable to synthesize the amino acid histidine.

A drawback is that the compounds that alter epigenetic factors (such as DNA methylation) would test negative in the Ames test. 

Other options:

Option A: Comet assay is a single gel electrophoresis technique to measure DNA damage and repair at the individual cell level. Fragments of DNA pulled through agarose gel in an electric field will appear as a 'Comet.' It is generally used in human and ecological biomonitoring.

Option B: Micronucleus testing (MN test) is one of the valid tests used as a quick check for detection of acute disorders caused by chemical substances in cells that have undergone cell division. 

Option C: Microtox Bio-assay uses photo-luminescent bacteria to analyze acute chemical toxicity.

questions.text: 185. Which of the following characteristics is seen in the condition affecting the child shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image of a child showing dark peeling patches over edematous limbs (flaky paint dermatosis) points to the diagnosis of kwashiorkor. The child will have a flag sign. 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterised by oedema. The oedema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs. It quickly develops into generalised oedema, affecting also the hands, arms, and face (moon face). Other signs of kwashiorkor are skin changes, which typically occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled, peeling patches with pale skin underneath that is easily infected, known as flaky paint dermatosis.

The hair is sparse and easily pulled out and may lose its curl. Alternate bands of hypopigmented and normally pigmented hair patterns are seen when the growth occurs in spurts, known as flag sign. Children with oedema are apathetic and often refuse to eat.

Simian or monkey facies and loose, wrinkled skin, with marked wasting of fat and muscle, are characteristic features of marasmus. The eyes may be sunken from loss of retro-orbital fat.

questions.text: 186. The given image is a dissected specimen of the posterior surface of the knee. If the structure marked in red arrow is injured, which of the following clinical manifestations would you expect?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in red is identified to be the common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve). Injury to this nerve will result in loss of ankle eversion.

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

* Foot drop

* Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and ankle eversion

* Diminishes sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space

* Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved

* High stepping gait is seen in this nerve injury

The common peroneal nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the L4 - L5 and S1 - S2 ventral rami. 

It descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa, until the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

* The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis, which are the evertors of the foot, and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot, except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.

* The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment, which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.



The course of the common peroneal nerve is shown below.



Other options:

Option A: Plantar flexion is caused by the action of muscles gastrocnemius and soleus innervated by the tibial nerve. 

Option C: Ankle inversion is caused by the action of the tibialis posterior muscle innervated by the tibial nerve.

Option D: Ankle reflex (S1, S2) is characterised by the plantar flexion of the foot when the calcaneal tendon is struck with a percussion hammer. Thus it is lost in lesions of the tibial nerve.

questions.text:
188. A patient presents 10 hours after an intentional overdose of paracetamol. Lab tests reveal elevated liver enzymes. N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) is started as an antidote. Which of the following statements are true?

* N-acetyl cysteine acts by replenishing glutathione stores

* The maximum recommended daily dose of paracetamol in adults is 10 g/day

* Chronic alcohol consumption increases the risk of hepatotoxicity

* Symptoms of toxicity appear immediately after ingestion
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1, 3.

The maximum recommended daily dose of paracetamol in adults is 4g/day (Statement 2), while ingestion of more than 10-15 g is considered toxic. In therapeutic doses, paracetamol is mainly metabolised by glucuronidation and sulfation, with a small fraction converted to CYP2E1 to a highly toxic metabolite, NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine). Paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose is a leading cause of acute liver failure.

Symptoms of paracetamol toxicity appear immediately after ingestion (Statement 4) is a false statement. Instead, toxicity progresses in stages: in the first 48 hours, patients may be asymptomatic or have nonspecific nausea, vomiting, and malaise; during 48-72 hours, hepatic injury manifests with right upper quadrant pain and elevated liver enzymes. The 72-96 hour stage is the peak of hepatotoxicity with jaundice, coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and risk of multi-organ failure; and beyond 4 days, patients either recover or progress to death.

N-acetyl cysteine acts by replenishing glutathione stores (Statement 1). It is the specific antidote. It enhances non-toxic metabolism of NAPQI, and is most effective when given within 8-16 hours. Supportive measures include activated charcoal if the patient presents within 4 hours of ingestion, and close monitoring of liver function, coagulation profile, renal function, and blood glucose. Severe cases with fulminant hepatic failure may require liver transplantation. 

Chronic alcohol consumption increases the risk of hepatotoxicity (Statement 3) because alcohol induces CYP2E1 and increases the formation of NAPQI. Normally, NAPQI is rapidly detoxified by conjugation with glutathione, but in overdose situations, glutathione stores are depleted, leading to hepatocellular necrosis and fulminant hepatic failure. However, when there is a paracetamol overdose along with acute alcohol consumption, a protective effect against paracetamol-induced liver injury is seen. This can be explained as acute alcohol use inhibits the hepatic microsomal enzymes (mainly CYP2E1) that convert paracetamol to its toxic metabolite, NAPQI. This protection disappears once ethanol is eliminated from the body, so the relative timing of alcohol and paracetamol ingestion is critical.

questions.text: 189. Which of the following findings suggests that the baby was live-born in a case of infanticide?

choices.text: Gelatinous tissue in the middle ear
Weight of lung 1/35th of body weight

questions.solution:
The baby will be considered live-born if the weight of the lung is 1/35th of the body weight.

Autopsy findings to differentiate before and after respiration:

Autopsy findings Before respiration After respiration
1. Shape of chest Flat; chest circumference is 1–2 cm less than the abdominal circumference Dome or arch-shaped
2. Position of the diaphragm At or above the 4th/5th rib At or below the 6th/7th rib
3. Lung margins Sharp Rounded
4. Lung consistency Dense, firm, non-crepitant Soft, spongy, elastic, crepitant
5. Lung weight 1/70th of body weight 1/35th of body weight
6. Lung color Uniformly reddish-brown or bluish-red Mottled or marbled appearance
7. Hydrostatic test Specific gravity is 1040–1050 Specific gravity is 940
8. Stomach Contains only mucin and sinks in water Contains mucin and air and floats in water
9. Middle ear Contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue Air replaces the embryonic tissue


 

Other tests for live birth:

* Breslau’s first life test (also known as Hydrostatic test/Raygat’s test) - The organ tested is the lung. It is based on the ability of the lung to sink or float in water.

* Breslau's second life test: It is based on the air entering stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. The stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water to check if they float or sink.

* Wreden’s test – This test is based on changes in the middle ear after birth

* Fodere’s test – This test is based on the increase in the weight of the lungs due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of the unrespired lung is 30–40 g, whereas the weight of respired lung is 60–66 g.

* Ploucquet’s test – This is based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.

* Unrespired lungs - 1/70

* Respired lungs - 1/35

Pearl PM1326: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

* Atelectasis

* Pulmonary edema

* Pneumonia

* Congenital syphilis

* Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration

* More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration

* Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

* Putrefied foetus

* Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

* Fetus is monstrous

* Fetus is macerated or mummified

* Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation

* Stomach contains milk

* Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

* Cells on a smear as shown in the image above.

* Thin, white homogenous discharge is present.

* pH of the discharge: 5.5

* Fishy odor on adding 10% KOH

choices.text: Only criterion 1 is sufficient to make a diagnosis
Any 3 out of these 4 criteria are needed
Criterion 1 with any two of criteria 2, 3, and 4 are required

questions.solution:
The given image shows clue cells that are seen in bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella. To make a diagnosis, any 3 out of these 4 criteria are needed. 

Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria out of which any 3 should be present:

* Thin, white, homogenous vaginal discharge

* pH of Vaginal fluid>4.5

* Fishy odor of discharge accentuated on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test)

* Presence of clue cells on microscopy. Many epithelial cells present with granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface, these cells are called clue cells.  

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection characterized by malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge. Causative organisms include:

* Gardnerella,

* Mobiluncus,

* Mycoplasma hominis 

Treatment is oral metronidazole 500 mg BD for 7 days. Alternatively, Ampicillin 500 mg or cephalosporin 500 mg bid for 7 days is also effective.

questions.text: 191. A patient presents with a productive cough, fever, and breathlessness. On examination, decreased breath sounds and dull note on percussion is noted on the right side. A CT scan of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and CT scan showing the split pleura sign is suggestive of empyema.

Empyema is defined as a collection of pus in the pleural cavity. Empyema is usually associated with pneumonia but may also develop after thoracic surgery or thoracic trauma.

At the margins of the empyema, the pleura can be seen dividing into parietal and visceral layers, the split pleura sign. It is the most sensitive and specific sign on CT and is helpful in distinguishing an empyema from a peripheral lung abscess.

CT scan showing split pleura sign:



Differentiating empyema from lung abscesses (Option B) may be difficult sometimes. CT is useful to distinguish an empyema from a lung abscess. Radiologically, a thicker and more irregular wall, and destruction rather than compression of the underlying lung suggest abscess rather than empyema. Unlike empyema, lung abscess is caused by trans diaphragmatic extension of a liver abscess or by bronchopleural fistula.  Contrast-enhanced CT should be adopted to visualize the margins and any associated vascular or airway complications. CT findings of lung abscess are similar to radiographs, with thick-walled, discrete cavitating lesions containing fluid, with or without gas.

The below image shows a lung abscess as the thick-walled cavitary lesion in the right lung, The diffuse ground glass infiltrates present in both lungs represent pneumonia.



Other options:

Option C: Pleural effusion on CT scan appears as free fluid in the dependent parts of the pleural cavity. It does not show any enhancement.

Option D: Hemothorax on CT scan may show areas of hyperdensity, which have a varying appearance dependent on age. A hematocrit effect with layering of blood may be seen in a subacute stage.

questions.text: 192. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the placental separation method shown in the image below?

choices.text: It is commonly known as Schultz method
The maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva
It is an abnormal method of placental separation

questions.solution:
The above image shows the Mathews-Duncan method of placental separation where the maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

Placental separation occurs during the third stage of labour. There are two normal mechanisms by which placental separation may occur:

Schultze method:

* The separation begins at the centre of the placenta (fetal surface). Hence, this is the first part to descend and appear at vulva.

* The blood collects into a membranous sac behind the placenta, leading to the formation of retroplacental clot.

* Bleeding does not occur until the placenta is completely extruded.

Mathews-Duncan method:

* The separation of the placenta begins at the peripheral edge of the placenta. Hence, the maternal surface appears first.

* The blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall, and escapes out from the vagina. There is no formation of retroplacental clot and the bleeding is profuse in this method of placental separation.

* It is much less common than Schultze method.



A. Central separation of the placenta, known as Schultze method

B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

Signs of placental separation: 

* The uterus becomes globular, firm and ballottable (earliest sign to appear).

* Schroeder's sign: Slight rise of fundal height as the separated placenta comes down in the lower segment and uterus rests over it. 

* Slight suprapubic bulging due to separated placenta distending the lower segment.

* Kustner's sign: On pushing, the uterus cephalad with a hand on the abdomen, the cord no longer recedes.

* A sudden gush of blood

* Permanent lengthening of the cord.

Pearl PM1824: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: 193. A 47-year-old female patient presents with slow progressive hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus for the last few years. Otoscopy reveals the following findings. What is the embryological origin of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a middle-aged woman with progressive hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus and a red mass behind an intact tympanic membrane is suggestive of an intratympanic glomus tumour. The embryological origin of an intratympanic glomus tumour is neural crest cells.

Glomus tumours are the most common benign tumours of the middle ear. The tumors comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies which resemble carotid bodies. Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IXth cranial nerve. 

Signs seen in intratympanic glomus tumour are -

* Rising sun sign when tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear

* Pulsation or Brown sign: when the ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel's speculum the tumour pulsates and blanches, this reverses when pressure is released.

Other presentations of glomus tumour include- bleeding polyp if the tympanic membrane is breached and pressure symptoms causing cranial nerve palsies. These are -

* Dysphagia and hoarseness with unilateral paralysis of the soft palate, due to IX and X nerve

* Vocal cord paralysis due to X nerve

* Weakness of the trapezius and sternomastoid muscles - XI nerve

* Atrophy of half of the tongue - XII nerve

They are diagnosed by CT scan, MRI and four-vessel angiography mainly. It is treated by surgery, radiation, embolization, or a combination of them. 

Note - Glomus tumors are highly vascular tumors hence biopsy is never done and their origin is not from angioblasts.

questions.text: 194. A researcher looks at an electron microscope image of a sensory receptor and remarks that it is responsible for touch sensation and sustained pressure. Which layer of the skin contains the receptor?
questions.solution:
The receptors responsible for touch sensation and sustained pressure are the Merkel cells, which are found in the stratum basale, denoted by '4' in the image above.

Merkel cells are dendritic endings that are found in hairy skin, taste buds, tactile areas of glabrous skin, eccrine sweat glands, and in regions of high tactile activity. They are immunoreactive against met-enkephalins, vasoactive intestinal polypeptides, and neuron-specific enolase and present in higher numbers in sun-exposed skin.

Destruction of Merkel cells is seen in vitiligo, and auto-antibodies against the cells are noted in conditions like pemphigus and graft-versus-host disease. Merkel cell hyperplasia, on the other hand, is seen in neurofibromas, neurilemmomas, and nodular prurigo.

The other layers of the skin are seen in the image below.



Other options:

Option A: Stratum granulosum/stratum lucidum (depending on the thickness of the section) contains flattened keratinocytes with keratohyalin granules; the stratum lucidum is a translucent layer observed in thick (glabrous) skin, like palms/soles.​

Option C: Stratum corneum is the outermost, anucleate, keratin-rich layer responsible for the protective barrier function of skin.​

Option D: Stratum spinosum is composed of several layers of polygonal keratinocytes connected by desmosomes ("prickle cell layer"). Also contains Langerhans cells (antigen-presenting immune cells).​

questions.text: 196. Which of the following is not a draining tributary of the azygos system of veins?
questions.solution:
1st right posterior intercostal vein is not a draining tributary of the azygos system of veins. 1st right posterior intercostal vein drains to the right brachiocephalic vein. 

The azygos system of veins drains the thoracic wall and the upper lumbar region. It forms a connecting channel between the superior and inferior venae cavae. It occupies the upper part of the posterior abdominal wall and the posterior mediastinum. It also connects the portal, caval system, and vertebral venous systems.

It is formed by the union of the lumbar azygos, right subcostal and right ascending lumbar veins. It enters the thorax by passing through the aortic opening in the diaphragm. It ascends up to the 4th thoracic vertebra, arching forward over the root of the right lung, and ends by joining the posterior aspect of the superior vena cava before piercing the pericardium. 

Tributaries of the azygous system of veins:

* The right superior intercostal vein (Option A) is formed by the union of the 2,3 and 4th posterior intercostal veins.

* 5-11th right posterior intercostal veins (Option B)

* Hemi-azygos vein at the level of the lower border of the 8th thoracic vertebra.

* Accessory hemiazygos vein at the level of the upper border of the 8th thoracic vertebra.

* Right bronchial vein (Option D), near the terminal end of the azygos vein

* Several oesophageal, mediastinal, pericardial veins. 

The hemi-azygos vein is formed by the union of the left lumbar azygos, left ascending lumbar, and left subcostal veins.

9th to 11th left posterior intercostal veins and esophageal veins drain into the hemi-azygous vein. It is also known as the inferior hemi-azygos vein.

The accessory hemiazygos vein is also known as the superior hemiazygos vein. 5th to 8th left posterior intercostal veins and sometimes the left bronchial veins drain into the accessory hemiazygos vein.

questions.text:
197. A patient comes with complaints of dizziness and is found to have unidirectional nystagmus on examination. Suspecting a peripheral cause of vertigo, which of the following would you consider in the differential diagnosis?

* Acoustic neuroma

* Meniere's disease

* Basilar migraine

* Vestibular neuronitis

* Vertebrobasilar insufficiency
questions.solution:
1, 2, and 4 will be the differential diagnoses for the peripheral causes of vertigo.

Acoustic neuroma, Meniere's disease, and vestibular neuronitis are examples of peripheral causes of vertigo, as they involve the vestibular end organs and vestibular nerve.

Disorders of the vestibular system cause vertigo and are divided into peripheral and central causes. Peripheral causes of vertigo involve the internal ear and vestibular nerve before it enters the brainstem. Vertigo is the most common cause of dizziness and refers to a sense of spinning or other motion that may be physiological, occurring during/after a sustained head rotation, or pathological, due to vestibular dysfunction. It is due to the asymmetry of vestibular inputs from the two labyrinths or in their central pathway.

Central causes of vertigo are associated with other central nervous system signs such as dysarthria, diplopia, and ataxia.  Vertigo is also associated with nystagmus, which is a rhythmical, involuntary, and oscillatory movement of the eyes. It can be horizontal, vertical, or rotatory. The following features can be used to differentiate between peripheral and central nystagmus.

Nystagmus Peripheral lesion Central lesion
Latency 2-20 seconds No latency
Duration Less than one minute More than one minute
Direction Fixed Changes
Fatiguability Fatiguable Nonfatiguable
Associated symptoms Severe vertigo None or slight




Basilar migraine (Statement 3): This is typically considered a central, not a peripheral, cause of vertigo. It's associated with migraine headaches and is characterised by brainstem aura symptoms. Therefore, it should not be included in the differential for a peripheral cause of vertigo.

Vertebrobasilar insufficiency (Statement 5): Like basilar migraine, vertebrobasilar insufficiency is a central cause of vertigo. This would not be typically included in a differential diagnosis focusing on peripheral causes of vertigo.

questions.text: 198. A chronic asthmatic patient who is on inhaled steroids presented with a history of a mild burning sensation in his mouth that is aggravated while eating spicy foods. The oral examination showed creamy white patches on the oral mucosa. The wet mount microscopy of the scraping obtained from the patches is given below. This organism is a ________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of creamy white patches on the oral mucosa and the wet mount microscopy showing budding and pseudohyphae are suggestive of oral candidiasis caused by candida, which is a yeast-like fungi.

Fungi are eukaryotic organisms with a rigid cell wall made of chitin and mannan and true nuclei with the nuclear membrane and paired chromosomes. They divide sexually, asexually, or by both processes and can be unicellular or multicellular. They are classified into 4 types based on their morphology :

* Yeast

* Yeast-like

* Molds

* Dimorphic fungi

Candida species are yeast-like fungi, which normally inhabit the skin and mucosa. Candida albicans is an ovoid or spherical budding cell, which produces pseudohyphae both in tissues and in culture. Candidiasis is an opportunistic endogenous infection. Risk factors include treatment with corticosteroids or antibiotics, high levels of glucose, and AIDS.

Diagnosis includes :

* Gram staining - Gram-positive budding cells with pseudohyphae.

* Sabouraud agar culture - Creamy white smooth colonies with yeasty odor.

* Corn meal agar culture - Candida albicans form chlamydospores.

* Reynolds Braude phenomenon - Candida albicans form germ tubes when incubated in human serum.

* CHROMagar - Candida albicans colonies appear green.

Treatment includes topical clotrimazole, nystatin, and fluconazole.

Pearl PM1761: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

* Yeast

* Yeast-like

* Molds

* Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding

* Oval to round forms

* Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.



 

Yeast like:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding or binary fission

* Spherical or oval forms

* Pseudohyphae may be seen.

* Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.



 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

* Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate

* Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.

* Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.



 

Dimorphic fungi

* Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.

* Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.

* Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: 200. A 60-year-old man on warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation is taken for an emergency surgery after trauma. He develops excessive bleeding in the surgical field. His platelet counts and fibrinogen levels are within normal limits. If a thromboelastography is done to evaluate the cause of bleeding, which tracing would most likely correspond to his condition?
questions.solution:
If thromboelastography is done, the tracing would correspond to image marked 1.

The patient is on warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation. Warfarin acts by reducing the activity of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors(Ⅱ, Ⅶ, Ⅸ, Ⅹ). This delays the initiation of clot formation.

On thromboelastography, the parameter that reflects the clotting factor is the R-time(Reaction time). Hence, warfarin leads to prolonged R-time, represented by image 1. Since the platelet counts and fibrinogen levels are normal, the subsequent clot kinetics - K time, ⍺ angle, and maximum amplitude remain within normal limits.

Thromboelastography (TEG) is a non-invasive test that quantifies the ability of whole blood to form a clot. It tests the entire coagulation pathway. The thromboelastography curve has the following parts:

* Reaction time/ R-time signifies the time from start to the initial fibrin formation. It represents the clotting factor activity. Prolonged R-time is seen in deficiency of clotting factors, anticoagulant therapy(heparin, warfarin). Short R-time is seen in a hypercoagulable state.

* Kinetics/K is the time from initial clot formation until it reaches a defined strength. It depends upon fibrinogen levels.

* α-angle is the angle formed by the slope of the TEG curve during the K-time phase. It represents the rate at which the fibrin cross-linking occurs. This depends mainly on the concentration of fibrin.

* Maximum amplitude (MA) represents the maximum strength of a clot. This depends on platelet number and function. 

* LY-30 signifies the extent of clot lysis, and A-30 signifies the amplitude of the clot left behind. Both these values are measured 30 minutes after MA. They depend on the presence of plasmin and its activators.



The following image shows different tracings of thromboelastography:
